elements.content: Glycoluril-based molecular clip L bearing two N,N′-chelating sites and a rigid cavity has been prepared. With L, one metallomacrocycle and three metal-organic frameworks, [Cu(L)(OAc)2(H2O)·2H2O] n (1), [Co(L)2(NO3)2(H2O)2·4H2O] n (2), [Zn(L)2(NO3)2(H2O)2·7H2O] n (3), and [Cu(L)(I)·DMF] n (4) were crystallized, which display three different structure types. In 1, two ligands are arranged in a face-to-face conformation to coordinate two Cu(II) ions from opposite directions through axial positions, generating a pesudo-rectangular metallomacrocycle. Polymer 2 is an 1D double ribbons. Interestingly, each double ribbons is connected by hydrogen bond with the result that the channels are formed and run parallel to the ab diagonal, and the water chains with the symbol C4 are located within the channels. Polymer 3 exhibits the same topological morphology as polymer 2. However, each double ribbons in 3 is connected by a different type of hydrogen bond with the result that the channels are formed along the b axis. Polymer 4 is a two-dimensional (2D) tubular sheet constructed by an unprecedented [CuI]∞ column and clip ligand L. The type of the [CuI]∞ column can be described as a zigzag chain and has been rarely reported. The DMF solvent molecules are located within the channels.

elements.content: A novel series of discrete and polymeric metal-organic frameworks were constructed from a glycoluril-based molecular clip under mild solution conditions. Their crystal packing, hydrogen bonds, TG measurements, and photoluminescence or SHG properties were investigated.
elements.clean_text: A novel series of discrete and polymeric metal-organic frameworks were constructed from a glycoluril-based molecular clip under mild solution conditions. Their crystal packing, hydrogen bonds, TG measurements, and photoluminescence or SHG properties were investigated.

elements.content: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are currently of significant interest and importance, not only because of their fascinating variety of architectures and topologies but also because of their potential applications as functional materials, particularly in molecular magnetism, catalysis, gas sorption, fluorescent sensing, and optoelectronic devices. The directed assembly of MOFs from discrete organic ligands has received considerable attention. Because organic ligands are some of the most important factors in determining the ultimate structures that are related to their corresponding physical and chemical properties, the design and synthesis of specific organic ligands continues to be an area of great interest in coordination chemistry. During past decades, a number of organic ligands, including rigid linear, semirigid and flexible organic spacers with various topologies and coordination natures, have been designed and synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are currently of significant interest and importance, not only because of their fascinating variety of architectures and topologies but also because of their potential applications as functional materials, particularly in molecular magnetism, catalysis, gas sorption, fluorescent sensing, and optoelectronic devices. The directed assembly of MOFs from discrete organic ligands has received considerable attention. Because organic ligands are some of the most important factors in determining the ultimate structures that are related to their corresponding physical and chemical properties, the design and synthesis of specific organic ligands continues to be an area of great interest in coordination chemistry. During past decades, a number of organic ligands, including rigid linear, semirigid and flexible organic spacers with various topologies and coordination natures, have been designed and synthesized.

elements.content: Molecular clips based on concave glycoluril unit or its derivatives (dimethyl-, diphenyl- and di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril), as specific organic spacers, have been widely investigated in recognition, organization, and assembly, but there are rarely studies of its characters as building block in metal-organic frameworks. We could imagine that the clip ligands, because of their concave structures, would offer the possibility of the construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by linear ligands, which are widely used by chemists in the generation of coordination framework. This concave ligand-directed approach did result in various new discrete and polymeric coordination complexes, some with open channels and excellent structures.

We could imagine that the clip ligands, because of their concave structures, would offer the possibility of the construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by linear ligands, which are widely used by chemists in the generation of coordination framework. This concave ligand-directed approach did result in various new discrete and polymeric coordination complexes, some with open channels and excellent structures.

elements.content: Recently, our research group has provided a series of rigid and semirigid clip molecules based on di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril and investigated their characters in recognition and assembly. As an in-depth analysis and part of our systemic investigation of crystal structure based on the concave ligand of this type, we herein report the self-assembly and characterization of four discrete and polymeric MOFs via a new type of subunit L.

As an in-depth analysis and part of our systemic investigation of crystal structure based on the concave ligand of this type, we herein report the self-assembly and characterization of four discrete and polymeric MOFs via a new type of subunit L.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. IR spectras were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer PE-983 infrared spectrometer as KBr pellets with absorption in 4000−400 cm−1. NMR spectras were recorded in CDCl3 on a Varian Mercury 400 spectrometer and resonances (δ) are given in parts per million relative to tetramethylsilane. MS determinations were carried out on a Finnigan Trace MS spectrometer or by the ESI method on a Quattro LCZ instrument (Waters-Micromass, Manchester, U.K.) with nanospray inlet. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Vario EL III instrument. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphitemonochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a SHG signal from samples. The backward scattered SHG light was collected using a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurement

The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. IR spectras were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer PE-983 infrared spectrometer as KBr pellets with absorption in 4000-400 cm-1. NMR spectras were recorded in CDCl3 on a Varian Mercury 400 spectrometer and resonances (δ) are given in parts per million relative to tetramethylsilane. MS determinations were carried out on a Finnigan Trace MS spectrometer or by the ESI method on a Quattro LCZ instrument (Waters-Micromass, Manchester, U.K.) with nanospray inlet. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Vario EL III instrument. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with graphitemonochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation at room temperature. A pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm was used to generate a SHG signal from samples. The backward scattered SHG light was collected using a spherical concave mirror and passed through a filter that transmits only 532 nm radiation.

elements.content: A suspension of di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril (1.43 g, 5 mmol) in 37% aq formaldehyde (3.5 mL) and MeOH (30 mL) was brought to reflux under magnetic stirring. Pyridin-4-ylmethanamine (15 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was slowly added dropwise (over 1 h) to the mixture. Then refluxing was continued. The reaction was monitored by TLC. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the products were separated by column chromatography (silica gel) with the yield 70%, as illustrated in Scheme . X-ray quality crystals were grown from a CH2Cl2/MeOH solution at room temperature. IR (KBr): 3420 w, 3034 w, 2986 w, 2843 w, 1755 s, 1725 s, 1604 m, 1472 m, 1418 s, 1297 s, 1236 s, 1168 m, 1120 m, 1032 s, 986 m, 919 m, 880 m, 862 w, 792 m, 736 w, 720 w, cm−1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.32 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 6 H), 3.88 (s, 4 H), 4.28−4.35 (m, 8 H), 4.84 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 4 H), 7.32 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 4 H), 8.60 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 4 H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 6.80, 47.16, 53.00, 56.41, 68.92, 116.44, 138.78, 142.88, 151.39, 158.00. MS (EI): m/z (%) = 550 (8) [M+], 233 (34), 217 (12), 121 (13), 95 (13), 93 (100), 76 (15), 64 (52), 50 (10).

elements.content: To a solution of L (55.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 15 mL CH2Cl2 was added a solution of Cu(OAc)2·H2O (39.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) at 25 °C. After being stirred for 3 h at 50 °C, the reaction mixture was filtered, and slow evaporation of the filtrate produced blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis (yield 31% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C30H42N8O13Cu: C, 45.85; H, 5.39; N, 14.26. Found: C, 45.76; H, 5.55; N, 14.45. elements.content: Crystals mounted on glass fiber were studied with a Bruker SMART APEX CCD Detector single-crystal X-ray diffractometer with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) source equipped with a sealed tube X-ray source at 25 °C. Preliminary unit cell constants were determined with a set of 45 narrow frame (0.3° in ω) scans. A data sets consisted of 1286 frames of intensity data collected with a frame width of 0.3° in ω, a counting time of 10 s/frame, and a crystal-to-detector distance of 5.0 cm. The double pass method of scanning was used to exclude any noise. The collected frames were integrated by using an orientation matrix determined from the narrow frame scans. SMART and SAINT software packages were used for data collection and data integration. Analysis of the integrated data did not reveal any decay. Final cell constants were determined by a global refinement of 8192 reflections (θ < 25.0°). Collected data were corrected for absorbance by using SADABS based on the Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. Structure solution and refinement were carried out with the SHELXTL-PLUS software package and the structure solved by the direct method. Full-matrix least-squares refinement was carried out by minimizing (F o 2 − F c 2)2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically; hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically or assigned isotropic displacement coefficients U(H) = 1.2U(C) or 1.5U(C-methyl), and their coordinates were allowed to ride on their respective atoms. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table. The pore volumes of the frameworks were calculated using the program PLATON; the guest molecules and anion moieties were omitted in these calculations. Cavity dimensions were calculated by overlapping rigid spheres with van der Waals radii for each element: O, 1.52; N, 1.55; C, 1.7; Co, 2.0; Cu, 1.4; and Zn, 1.39 Å. (hydrogen atoms were omitted in all cases for simplicity).

X-ray Structural Crystallography

Crystals mounted on glass fiber were studied with a Bruker SMART APEX CCD Detector single-crystal X-ray diffractometer with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) source equipped with a sealed tube X-ray source at 25 °C. Preliminary unit cell constants were determined with a set of 45 narrow frame (0.3° in ω) scans. A data sets consisted of 1286 frames of intensity data collected with a frame width of 0.3° in ω, a counting time of 10 s/frame, and a crystal-to-detector distance of 5.0 cm. The double pass method of scanning was used to exclude any noise. The collected frames were integrated by using an orientation matrix determined from the narrow frame scans. SMART and SAINT software packages were used for data collection and data integration. Analysis of the integrated data did not reveal any decay. Final cell constants were determined by a global refinement of 8192 reflections (θ < 25.0°). Collected data were corrected for absorbance by using SADABS based on the Laue symmetry using equivalent reflections. Structure solution and refinement were carried out with the SHELXTL-PLUS software package and the structure solved by the direct method. Full-matrix least-squares refinement was carried out by minimizing (F o 2 - F c 2)2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically; hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically or assigned isotropic displacement coefficients U(H) = 1.2U(C) or 1.5U(C-methyl), and their coordinates were allowed to ride on their respective atoms. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table. The pore volumes of the frameworks were calculated using the program PLATON; the guest molecules and anion moieties were omitted in these calculations. Cavity dimensions were calculated by overlapping rigid spheres with van der Waals radii for each element: O, 1.52; N, 1.55; C, 1.7; Co, 2.0; Cu, 1.4; and Zn, 1.39 Å. (hydrogen atoms were omitted in all cases for simplicity).

So far, rigid and flexible organic bidentate and multidentate ligands have been the main theme in the chemistry of coordination polymers. All these bidentate and multidentate N-donor containing ligands have proven to be among the most important types of organic ligands for the design and construction of coordination polymers exhibiting remarkable polymeric structural motifs. However, up to now, very little attention has been paid to the coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from semirigid organic ligands, especially semirigid organic clip ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Ligand Synthesis and Structural Analysis

So far, rigid and flexible organic bidentate and multidentate ligands have been the main theme in the chemistry of coordination polymers. All these bidentate and multidentate N-donor containing ligands have proven to be among the most important types of organic ligands for the design and construction of coordination polymers exhibiting remarkable polymeric structural motifs. However, up to now, very little attention has been paid to the coordination polymers or supramolecular complexes generated from semirigid organic ligands, especially semirigid organic clip ligands.

elements.content: Semirigid ligands fill a void between rigid and flexible organic ligands and offer the possibility for construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by rigid or flexible ligands. We are interested in how different types of semirigid linking groups impact the coordination and supramolecular motifs of a variety of metal complexes based on concave molecular clip derived from di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril. Following this approach, we have expanded concave di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril to the semirigid ligand L. The semirigid clip ligand L was synthesized by the reaction of di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril and pyridin-4-ylmethanamine in the presence of CH2O in MeOH at reflux temperature in moderate yield according to published procedures.
elements.clean_text: Semirigid ligands fill a void between rigid and flexible organic ligands and offer the possibility for construction of frameworks with novel patterns not easily achievable by rigid or flexible ligands. We are interested in how different types of semirigid linking groups impact the coordination and supramolecular motifs of a variety of metal complexes based on concave molecular clip derived from di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril. Following this approach, we have expanded concave di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril to the semirigid ligand L. The semirigid clip ligand L was synthesized by the reaction of di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril and pyridin-4-ylmethanamine in the presence of CH2O in MeOH at reflux temperature in moderate yield according to published procedures.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , clip molecule L is built up from four fused rings, namely two nearly planar imidazole five-membered rings that adopt envelope conformation with the CO groups at the flap position and two nonplanar triazine six-membered rings that adopt a chair conformation. The distance between the two carbonyl oxygen atoms (O1−O2) of the glycoluril moiety is 5.238 Å. The distance between the centers of the two pyridyl rings is 6.305 Å, and the two pyridyl rings are almost parallel with the dihedral angle about 3°. Because of the presence of the polarized carbonyl groups and the electron-rich nitrogen atoms in the cavity, the clip molecule L is expected to bind guests by means of hydrogen bonding and the cavity effect.

Because of the presence of the polarized carbonyl groups and the electron-rich nitrogen atoms in the cavity, the clip molecule L is expected to bind guests by means of hydrogen bonding and the cavity effect.

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained as a discrete bimetallic complex with a rectangular-shaped structure. As indicated in Figure , the overall structure of L is expected to be an organic clip, and two-coordination 4-pyridine arms are nearly parallel and point in the same direction. In addition, two 4-pyridine arms attached to glycoluril unit are rotationally free and are thus capable of adjusting to match the metal coordination preference well. The structure consists of a Cu2(OAc)4(H2O)2 motif and two organic clips per formula unit where each Cu(II) atom exhibits a specially distorted heptalateral configuration with a N2O5 donor set. The Cu atom is coordinated by two individual pyridyl nitrogen atoms with Cu−N bond distances 2.000(6) and 2.047(6) Å, respectively. Five additional positions are occupied by oxygen atoms from two bidentate chelating acetate and a coordinated water molecule with Cu−O bond distances varying from 1.992(6) to 2.692(6) Å. Among five Cu−O bond distances, three Cu−O bond lengths (Cu(1)−O(8), Cu(1)−O(10), and Cu(1)−O(11)) are in the range 2.5−2.7 Å, indicating the weak Cu−O interaction. These bond lengths are comparable to those reported values. The longest distance between opposite carbon atoms (C(11) and C(15a)) is 17.75 Å. The width, as defined by the intramolecular Cu(II)···Cu(II) distance, is 5.81 Å. The distance between the centers of the two pyridyl rings is 5.537 Å, which is much shorter than that in free ligand L. It may be caused by the two classical hydrogen bonds O(7)−H(11A)−O(11)# [symmetry code: # −x + 2, −y + 1, −z + 1], which pull the Cu(II) ions closer. Thus, the copper rectangle herein is strained. Each ring stacks on its neighbors forming a 1D channel by hydrogen bond interactions O(9)−H(11B)−O(11)# [symmetry code: # −x + 3, −y + 1, −z + 1] extended along the crystallographic a axis, which generates a three-dimensional network sustained by hydrogen bond contacts between metallomacrocycles and free water molecules. The water solvent molecules are located between these hydrogen bond driven layers (see the ).

Crystal Structure of [Cu(L)(OAc)2(H2O)⋅2H2O] n  (1)

Compound 1 was obtained as a discrete bimetallic complex with a rectangular-shaped structure. As indicated in Figure , the overall structure of L is expected to be an organic clip, and two-coordination 4-pyridine arms are nearly parallel and point in the same direction. In addition, two 4-pyridine arms attached to glycoluril unit are rotationally free and are thus capable of adjusting to match the metal coordination preference well. The structure consists of a Cu2(OAc)4(H2O)2 motif and two organic clips per formula unit where each Cu(II) atom exhibits a specially distorted heptalateral configuration with a N2O5 donor set. The Cu atom is coordinated by two individual pyridyl nitrogen atoms with Cu-N bond distances 2.000(6) and 2.047(6) Å, respectively. Five additional positions are occupied by oxygen atoms from two bidentate chelating acetate and a coordinated water molecule with Cu-O bond distances varying from 1.992(6) to 2.692(6) Å. Among five Cu-O bond distances, three Cu-O bond lengths (Cu(1)-O(8), Cu(1)-O(10), and Cu(1)-O(11)) are in the range 2.5-2.7 Å, indicating the weak Cu-O interaction. These bond lengths are comparable to those reported values. The longest distance between opposite carbon atoms (C(11) and C(15a)) is 17.75 Å. The width, as defined by the intramolecular Cu(II)⋅⋅⋅Cu(II) distance, is 5.81 Å. The distance between the centers of the two pyridyl rings is 5.537 Å, which is much shorter than that in free ligand L. It may be caused by the two classical hydrogen bonds O(7)-H(11A)-O(11)# [symmetry code: # -x + 2, -y + 1, -z + 1], which pull the Cu(II) ions closer. Thus, the copper rectangle herein is strained. Each ring stacks on its neighbors forming a 1D channel by hydrogen bond interactions O(9)-H(11B)-O(11)# [symmetry code: # -x + 3, -y + 1, -z + 1] extended along the crystallographic a axis, which generates a three-dimensional network sustained by hydrogen bond contacts between metallomacrocycles and free water molecules. The water solvent molecules are located between these hydrogen bond driven layers (see the ).

elements.content: Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized by solution reactions. The slow diffusion of an organic solution (CHCl3 or CH2Cl2) of L into a MeOH solution of MX2 (M = Zn(II) or Co(II); X = NO3 −) afforded 1:2 M(II)−L complexes with an interesting bimetallic macroring-containing double ribbons. It is noteworthy that all these slow diffusion reactions are not affected by the metal-to-ligand molar ratio, solvent intermedia, and counterions.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Co(L)2(NO3)2(H2O)2⋅4H2O] n  (2) and [Zn(L)2(NO3)2(H2O)2⋅7H2O] n  (3)

Compounds 2 and 3 were synthesized by solution reactions. The slow diffusion of an organic solution (CHCl3 or CH2Cl2) of L into a MeOH solution of MX2 (M = Zn(II) or Co(II); X = NO3 -) afforded 1:2 M(II)-L complexes with an interesting bimetallic macroring-containing double ribbons. It is noteworthy that all these slow diffusion reactions are not affected by the metal-to-ligand molar ratio, solvent intermedia, and counterions.

elements.content: The structures of 2 and 3 are very similar except for slight differences of some bond distances and bond angles (for comparison see Table ). Moreover, in unit cells of 2, four free water molecules are observed, whereas in that of 3, only two free water molecules are observed. Hence, only the structure of 2 is discussed in detail here. The figures of compound 3 are provided in the Supporting Information. As shown in Figure a, the structure of 2 has only one repeating metallic structural motif, with each crystallographically unique Co(II) metal center in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, {CoN4O2}, which is defined by four nitrogen donors from four L ligands in the equatorial plane, with two monodentate coordination water oxygen groups in the axial positions. In 2, the Co−N bond lengths for the coordinated pyridyl groups are 2.163(2) Å, which are comparable to the corresponding Co−N bond lengths found in related complexes such as CoCuC33Cl10H32N9O7P3 and CoC8H26N10O2Cl. The axial Co−O distance of 2.153(4) Å is slightly longer than the corresponding Co−O bond distance in GdCo2C56H62Cl6N13O15P2S2, whereas the Co−O distances varying from 2.070(4) to 2.103(4) Å. Two pyridyl groups of L form dihedral angle of ca. 72° with the correspondingly pyridine ring plane. The C3−C6−N2 bond angle is 111.4°, which is very close to the corresponding bond angles N2−C7−C6 and N7−C22−C23 in free ligand L.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the repetition of the {CoN4O2} 36-membered bimetallic macrocycle-containing structural motif of compound 2 generates an infinite double ribbons extended in the bc plane (Figure b, left). All 36-membered bimetallic macrocycles are interlaced to each other crossing the cobalt nodes to generate rhombus-like cavities possessing a crystallographic 21 screw axis along the Co(II)···Co(II) direction, in which one water molecule is incorporated in each cavity. As illustrated in Figure b (right), the intracage opposite Co(II)···Co(II) and C(11)···C(11d) diagonal distances across the individual rhombic cavity are ca. 12 and 16 Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that the repetition of the {CoN4O2} 36-membered bimetallic macrocycle-containing structural motif of compound 2 generates an infinite double ribbons extended in the bc plane (Figure b, left). All 36-membered bimetallic macrocycles are interlaced to each other crossing the cobalt nodes to generate rhombus-like cavities possessing a crystallographic 21 screw axis along the Co(II)⋅⋅⋅Co(II) direction, in which one water molecule is incorporated in each cavity. As illustrated in Figure b (right), the intracage opposite Co(II)⋅⋅⋅Co(II) and C(11)⋅⋅⋅C(11d) diagonal distances across the individual rhombic cavity are ca. 12 and 16 Å, respectively.

elements.content: The resulting 1D structure is cross-linked by classical hydrogen-bond interactions between nitrate ions, coordinated water molecules, and free water molecules, thus producing the 2D framework. Moreover, X-ray structure analysis clearly reveals that nitrate ions act as a powerful bridging linker and play crucial roles in the formation of the 2D network (Figure c and Table ). Three oxygen atoms in nitrate ions are the bridging arms, in which two oxygen atoms contact with free water molecules, and the residual oxygen atom is responsible for the construction of 2D network by linking double ribbons through hydrogen bonding between nitrate ions and coordination water molecules.

Three oxygen atoms in nitrate ions are the bridging arms, in which two oxygen atoms contact with free water molecules, and the residual oxygen atom is responsible for the construction of 2D network by linking double ribbons through hydrogen bonding between nitrate ions and coordination water molecules.

Interestingly, the major difference between the frameworks of 2 and 3 results from the different free water molecules in the channels. For 2, one-dimensional infinite water chains consisting of fused water tetramers were formed in the channels as shown in Figure d. According to Infantes’ classification, the water chains in 2 have the symbol C4, which consist of two-edge-shared four-membered clusters. In comparison to 2, only a 1D hydrogen bond network exists formed by nitrate ions as bridging arms in 3, and two oxygen atoms of nitrate ion are bound to the water dimers in the channels and similarly another oxygen atom contributes to link double ribbons through the same hydrogen-bonding model as that found in 2 (see the ). Large open channels were generated along the [011] direction for 2 and the [110] direction for 3, respectively (Figure e and the ).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/cwith two organic clips per formula unit and all atoms in general positions (Table). Each copper atom is surrounded by two nitrogen atoms of two symmetry-related clip ligands and two symmetry related iodine atoms within a distorted tetrahedron (Figure a and Table). Bond lengths and angles around the copper atoms are in the range of those found in other CuI coordination polymers containing a topologically similar coordination network. The copper atoms are connected via the iodine atoms to form CuI single zigzig chains as the CuX substructure. These chains are oriented in the direction of the crystallographic a-axis. They are connected via μ-N,N′ coordination by the clip ligands to a 2D tubular sheet parallel to [010] instead of a 3D diamondoid structure or a 2D layer usually generated from a metal-tetrahedron and linear rigid ligand, and this topological structure derived from the CuX substructure was first reported as we know (Figure b).

elements.content: Complexes 1−4 are stable at ambient conditions, and thermogravimetric experiments were performed to explore their thermal stabilities. For 1, the first weight loss of 4.79% of total weight in the 20−60 °C temperature range, corresponding to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit (expected 4.58%), and further lost 24.47% of total weight by 196 °C, corresponding to the loss of two coordinated acetyl groups (expected: 24.20%). For 2, the first weight loss occurs in the range of 55 to 160 °C, which is attributed to the departure of four free water molecules and two coordinated water molecules (obsd 7.91%, calcd 7.77%), followed by a plateau region ranging from 160 to 370 °C, and consecutive decompositions suggest the total destruction of the framework, whereas 3 exhibited weight loss of 11.40% in the 29−182 °C temperature range for three water molecules per formula unit (expected: 11.16%). For 4, the weight loss of 8.50% from 120 to 201 °C (calcd 8.97%) corresponds to the loss of one free DMF molecules per formula.

elements.content: Inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because of the higher thermal stability of inorganic−organic coordination polymers and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. In this context, the luminescence properties of L and polymeric compounds 3−4 were investigated in the solid state. As indicated in , L exhibits one emission maximum at 467 nm (λex = 420 nm). Compounds 3−4 based on L show an intense emission maximum at 449 nm for 3(λex = 399 nm; see the ), 495 nm with a shoulder band at 529 nm for 4 (λex =397 nm; see the ), respectively. For 3, the observed emissions are clearly caused by intraligand fluorescent emission because of emission bands similar to L. It is clear that bathochromic shift of emission occurs in 4, compared with compound 3, which is probably due to the differences of ligands and coordination environment around central metal ions, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. Complexes 3 and 4 may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue-fluorescent materials, because they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.

Luminescence Properties

Inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because of the higher thermal stability of inorganic-organic coordination polymers and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic-organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. In this context, the luminescence properties of L and polymeric compounds 3-4 were investigated in the solid state. As indicated in , L exhibits one emission maximum at 467 nm (λex = 420 nm). Compounds 3-4 based on L show an intense emission maximum at 449 nm for 3(λex = 399 nm; see the ), 495 nm with a shoulder band at 529 nm for 4 (λex =397 nm; see the ), respectively. For 3, the observed emissions are clearly caused by intraligand fluorescent emission because of emission bands similar to L. It is clear that bathochromic shift of emission occurs in 4, compared with compound 3, which is probably due to the differences of ligands and coordination environment around central metal ions, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. Complexes 3 and 4 may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue-fluorescent materials, because they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.

elements.content: As we know, noncentrosymmetric MOFs have attracted much attention because they are desired candidates for second-order nonlinear materials. Because of their high thermal stability, neutral noncentrosymmetric compounds 2 and 3 herein could be considered as potential NLO-active materials. For evaluation of their NLO activity, we have performed second harmonic generation (SHG) on powder samples of 2 and 3. The complexes 2 and 3 crystallize in a chiral space group, I222, which belongs to the crystal class orthorhombic. According to the principles proposed by Kurtz and Perry, the strength of the SHG efficiency of the complexes was tested by measuring the microcrystalline powder of the complexes. Preliminary experimental results show that 2 and 3 are SHG-active and display powder SHG efficiencies. The relative second harmonic intensity of 4 is 1 times versus 3 but versus ca. 0.3 times that of urea.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

As we know, noncentrosymmetric MOFs have attracted much attention because they are desired candidates for second-order nonlinear materials. Because of their high thermal stability, neutral noncentrosymmetric compounds 2 and 3 herein could be considered as potential NLO-active materials. For evaluation of their NLO activity, we have performed second harmonic generation (SHG) on powder samples of 2 and 3. The complexes 2 and 3 crystallize in a chiral space group, I222, which belongs to the crystal class orthorhombic. According to the principles proposed by Kurtz and Perry, the strength of the SHG efficiency of the complexes was tested by measuring the microcrystalline powder of the complexes. Preliminary experimental results show that 2 and 3 are SHG-active and display powder SHG efficiencies. The relative second harmonic intensity of 4 is 1 times versus 3 but versus ca. 0.3 times that of urea.

elements.content: A novel molecular clip L was prepared and its coordination chemistry was investigated by solution reactions. One pesudo-rectangular metallomacrocycle and three porous polymeric metal-organic frameworks were readily prepared via self-assembly through the use of L. X-ray crystallography, IR, elemental analysis, and XRPD data unambiguously established the proposed structure. For the first time, a clip ligand based on di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril has been introduced into the coordination polymer system. This study not only demonstrates that the nature of ligands and the geometric needs of metal atoms play an important role in the crystal packing of MOFs but also illustrates that the hydrogen bonds affect the formation of the supramolecular architecture. In addition, complexes 3 and 4 may be excellent candidates for blue-fluorescent materials, both 2 and 3 appear to be a candidate of novel hybrid inorganic−organic NLO materials. Meanwhile, structural information of the water chains in 2 affords a new example to understand the behavior of bulk water.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A novel molecular clip L was prepared and its coordination chemistry was investigated by solution reactions. One pesudo-rectangular metallomacrocycle and three porous polymeric metal-organic frameworks were readily prepared via self-assembly through the use of L. X-ray crystallography, IR, elemental analysis, and XRPD data unambiguously established the proposed structure. For the first time, a clip ligand based on di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril has been introduced into the coordination polymer system. This study not only demonstrates that the nature of ligands and the geometric needs of metal atoms play an important role in the crystal packing of MOFs but also illustrates that the hydrogen bonds affect the formation of the supramolecular architecture. In addition, complexes 3 and 4 may be excellent candidates for blue-fluorescent materials, both 2 and 3 appear to be a candidate of novel hybrid inorganic-organic NLO materials. Meanwhile, structural information of the water chains in 2 affords a new example to understand the behavior of bulk water.

A suspension of di(ethoxycarbonyl) glycoluril (1.43 g, 5 mmol) in 37% aq formaldehyde (3.5 mL) and MeOH (30 mL) was brought to reflux under magnetic stirring. Pyridin-4-ylmethanamine (15 mmol) in MeOH (20 mL) was slowly added dropwise (over 1 h) to the mixture. Then refluxing was continued. The reaction was monitored by TLC. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the products were separated by column chromatography (silica gel) with the yield 70%, as illustrated in Scheme . X-ray quality crystals were grown from a CH2Cl2/MeOH solution at room temperature. To a solution of L (55.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) in 15 mL CH2Cl2 was added a solution of Cu(OAc)2·H2O (39.0 mg, 0.20 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) at 25 °C. After being stirred for 3 h at 50 °C, the reaction mixture was filtered, and slow evaporation of the filtrate produced blue crystals suitable for X-ray analysis (yield 31% based on Cu). Anal. Calcd for C30H42N8O13Cu: C, 45.85; H, 5.39; N, 14.26. Found: C, 45.76; H, 5.55; N, 14.45. A solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg, 0.20 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was layered onto a solution of L (55.0 mg, 0.10 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (15 mL). Complexes 1−4 are stable at ambient conditions, and thermogravimetric experiments were performed to explore their thermal stabilities. For 1, the first weight loss of 4.79% of total weight in the 20−60 °C temperature range, corresponding to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit (expected 4.58%), and further lost 24.47% of total weight by 196 °C, corresponding to the loss of two coordinated acetyl groups (expected: 24.20%). For 2, the first weight loss occurs in the range of 55 to 160 °C, which is attributed to the departure of four free water molecules and two coordinated water molecules (obsd 7.91%, calcd 7.77%), followed by a plateau region ranging from 160 to 370 °C, and consecutive decompositions suggest the total destruction of the framework, whereas 3 exhibited weight loss of 11.40% in the 29−182 °C temperature range for three water molecules per formula unit (expected: 11.16%). For 4, the weight loss of 8.50% from 120 to 201 °C (calcd 8.97%) corresponds to the loss of one free DMF molecules per formula.

Luminescence Properties

Inorganic−organic hybrid coordination polymers have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as luminescent materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Because of the higher thermal stability of inorganic−organic coordination polymers and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of organic materials, syntheses of inorganic−organic coordination polymers by the judicious choice of conjugated organic spacers and transition metal centers can be an efficient method for obtaining new types of electroluminescent materials. In this context, the luminescence properties of L and polymeric compounds 3−4 were investigated in the solid state. As indicated in , L exhibits one emission maximum at 467 nm (λex = 420 nm). Compounds 3−4 based on L show an intense emission maximum at 449 nm for 3(λex = 399 nm; see the ), 495 nm with a shoulder band at 529 nm for 4 (λex =397 nm; see the ), respectively. For 3, the observed emissions are clearly caused by intraligand fluorescent emission because of emission bands similar to L. It is clear that bathochromic shift of emission occurs in 4, compared with compound 3, which is probably due to the differences of ligands and coordination environment around central metal ions, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. Complexes 3 and 4 may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue-fluorescent materials, because they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.
